content: do you have kids that are really obsessed with those blind bag collectors
toys that produce a ton of garbage and waste well if you do today I'm going to
show you how you can take the waste from one of those and turn it into some
pretty sweet scatter turn for tabletop gaming so I have a five-year-old
daughter and like a lot of five-year-olds she's totally obsessed
with and into these various toys that are blind bags and you got to collect
the whole set and you never know what you're gonna get and that's fine I get
the appeal of that but they're really frustrating because they're so often
just wrapped up in layers of waste and garbage like listen I get the appeal of
blind bag stuff for kids and surprises and I get why they're so profitable for
these companies but do they have to wrap them in like a hundred layers of waste
seriously have you seen an lol doll it's the stupidest thing that's ever been
invented in terms of packaging it's like this much toy for this much garbage it's
like the thing of nightmares for anyone who is even remotely concerned about the
environment my daughter's wasteful toys of choice however are Hatcher moles they
aren't as bad as some and the toys are decent and the waste is less than others
but one thing they produce are these plastic eggshells that just end up in
the trash for Easter we got her a pack of these and I thought you know I should
probably put the 2 shells aside and try to make something cool with them and I'm
glad I did because this project in my eyes is an absolute winner I figured I'd
throw these on some sort of base and add some goo and I'd get an instantly cool
prop for a dungeon or sci-fi battlefield for the bases I just grabbed some MDF
circles these are the kind of thing that you can often find in craft stores
they're great for projects like this you get them in all
sorts of shapes and sizes since I wanted them to have more of a natural beveled
edge I carefully carved down the edges to give them more of a taper because the
MDF is so soft it's really easy to safely do this and while this may look
dangerous it's not as long as you're practiced and in control of what you're
doing much like a chef peeling a potato or an Apple MDF is also really easy to
sand smooth especially on pieces this small it doesn't even require an orbital
or powered sander you can quickly do it by hand
I didn't taper the edges completely to nothing as I still wanted to kind of
preserve some of the strength of the edges to set the shelves in place and to
give the basis a nice ground texture I use some sculpting mold I totally love
this stuff for tasks like this it's pretty cheap really easy to work with
and it dries really strong and really quickly of course you could use any
number of different materials for the step joint compound air dry clay
two-part epoxy putty the list goes on but whatever you have and whatever you
prefer to work with is probably fine each material is just gonna have a
different set of pros and cons but we'll probably each end up getting the job
done one tip though when applying things to MDF that you want to bond really well
is that it helps a lot if you lightly wet the MDF first well assuming what
you're working with is water-based this will cause any adhesive to slightly
absorb into the wood making for a much stronger application
I didn't even actually glue the shells in place I just switched the pieces into
the sculpting mold before it was dry and that was more than enough thankfully I'd
also saved a bunch of the broken shell pieces that I could place in front of
the opening
but the shells did have two issues visually that I needed to deal with
there were some holes on the bases and also a really fine squiggly joint line
that ran across the whole shell you might not be able to see it on camera
but it's very visible in person I covered the holes with a dab of leftover
scope the mold that still hadn't dried and decided to create kind of like an
umbilical cord type thing that would come out of the end and that way I could
drape those over the shell and also cover the seams I thought about using
something like green stuff or Miller pot for this but since the great toilet
paper craze of 2020 seems to have died down it at least in my neck of the woods
I could return to using it as a crafting material so using one square and some
very watered-down PVA glue I twisted up a cord and draped it over the shell this
is a really easy way to make something like this that doesn't take too long to
dry and doesn't use any expensive material I thought the insides of the
shells still look too empty though and they had sort of a factory-produced
pattern that didn't quite look right so an easy fix was again to use some more
watered-down toilet paper and glue to just kind of stuff inside and create a
bit of an organic texture more sculpt a mold would also have worked just fine
but I didn't feel like mixing up a new batch I was thinking it would be really
neat though if these umbilical cords had some tiny vein-like tendrils coming off
of them so to do this I turn to lichen just the stuff that you see in bags that
basically every craft store it's a bit of a pain but if you break apart and
grab really tiny small strands of this you can create some great looking
effects the important thing is to make sure that they are really saturated and
super glue and completely attached to your piece if any bits are just sticking
up well they're almost certainly gonna break off at some point and probably
some point soon for the painting I decided to prime these out white
thinking you know that would be the best starting point for painting eggs for
some reason I chose to prime with a rattle-can
which was actually a bit of a mistake in this case
these pieces have a lot of little nooks and crannies and undersides that were
really hard to get to with the spray can it just sprays out with too much force
and you don't have much control over it so getting in those little hard-to-reach
spots creates a big risk of over spraying everything else as you apply
too much I really wasn't happy with the spray job so I let it dry and reap
rhymed it again with Vallejo primer through my airbrush the airbrush allows
for a lot more delicate control and makes it easier to get into the
hard-to-reach spots this time though I switched gears and sprayed it out black
first that way I could zennith I'll highlight everything with grey followed
by white and this would allow me to get a nice paint job on these with minimal
effort by using transparent inks I first sprayed out everything with a very
vibrant green ink this created a very nice look over that zenithal priming
then using a darker brownish green I
started spraying in some shadows in the appropriate areas this was really the
perfect project to practice my still pretty rudimentary airbrush skills on so
I really took advantage of that opportunity
but this was the point where things
started to go south I like the way things were looking but I wanted to give
those unbiblical chords more of a fleshy look I thought contrast paints would be
perfect for this I first brushed on a purple one and
while it looked okay didn't really look quite right so I decided to do another
coat of red contrast paint this well it kind of looked okay on the court itself
but I really wasn't careful enough with the application and so it kind of bled
on to the egg in a way that kind of looks sloppy and not right so
experimenting with the airbrush further I applied some burnt sienna ink the idea
here was to mute the red a little bit and kind of feather out that contrast
bleed it sort of worked but much like a quarantine haircut it just kept going a
little further and a little further until the whole thing was a disaster I
really was not happy with the paint job at all anymore and often I will continue
down a path just to go with it and see it through but I really like this build
and I wanted to do the paint job right and I still wanted to practice my
airbrush skills so I decided to try and pivot and fix it I went back in with a
white primer and tried to only paint out the shell leaving the cord this was a
great situation to practice more detailed and controlled airbrushing I
let the dark shadows that were already established show through the white and
didn't worry about the kind of speckled application of the primer as it was
actually looking kind of right for an eggshell this decision was one of the
best that I made on the whole project as it was a crucial step to actually
getting these to look the way I wanted for the most part I was able to stay in
the lines so to speak spraying on the white but there was of course some
overspray on the cords this was an easy fix though just a bit of sepia ink
carefully brushed on to cover those oversprayed areas the overspray on the
bases was corrected in the axing fashion but using some egg racks
earth shade I was pretty happy at this point and wanted to finish them off with
some nice slimy effects I figured some glossy contrast between the cords and
the shell would be great so I brushed on some vey ho water
effects to give them a really wet look gloss varnish or Mod Podge or anything
like that really would have worked just as well but I already had the water
effects out as I was about to use them on the following step for the weird
alien goo I used the water effects mixed with the most vibrant neon green ink
that I had on hand I just poured the stuff right in sloshed it around and let
it run wild I should point out though that after I let this stuff dry I had
lost a fair bit of it due to shrinking as well as running off the piece as it
dried so off-camera I did do a second application in the exact same fashion
what's really neat about using this sort of vibrant ink though is that if you
shut off the lights and put a black light on it they light up like crazy in
a really cool effect that you could actually consider implementing during an
in-person game to give the goo one more bit of hmm I created some drips for this
I switched to UV resin because it could set up and harden instantly the same
thing could be done with the water effects from earlier but you have to
wait quite a while for it to dry with the resin you can draw out the lines set
them with UV light and apply them right away using more resin as the adhesive
one interesting thing though is that the ink didn't want to mixed into the resin
properly which is interesting I've used other inks and paints with the resin in
the past and they mixed fine but this one wanted to separate and I was
actually kind of happy that it did because it gave it a really interesting
kind of speckled oily look that I thought was just a straight-up bonus
this is the part of the video where I usually try to say something encouraging
about how the project wasn't perfect but that's okay or that it didn't go as I
had planned but that doesn't matter but in all honesty I can't say that here in
my mind I love every single thing about the way this build
turned out I think they are straight-up pella cool I'm proud of my paint job on
them and I'm proud of the way that I used the leftover trash from a silly toy
to make them my only regret is that I haven't been saving these shells all
along and only had to to work with imagine a skirmish game where the whole
table is littered with these things I think that would be absolutely amazing
so what do you guys think personally I think this project is one of those
golden type elusive perfect projects for terrain builders that we're all after
and what I mean by that is that they're so universally useful in different
settings they would look right at home in the depths of a dungeon or cave in a
fantasy game setting like Dungeons and Dragons and they would look equally as
appropriate in the hull of some abandoned spacecraft in a sci-fi RPG or
they would look great on the table of some sort of skirmish war game like
really you can get a lot of mileage out of these eggs even though they are in a
way very specific maybe I'm wrong I don't know what do you guys think I hope
that you enjoyed this video found it entertaining useful helpful if you did
hit the like button and let me know your thoughts in the comment section below do
you have any toys that your kids are obsessed with that produce some sort of
similar trash that maybe could be repurposed in a creative way let me know
and I'm gonna look into those as well if I can steer my kid into liking things
that create usable garbage I'm gonna do so if you want to pick up any tools or
supplies for your own hobby needs maybe something like sculpt a mold or UV resin
or a black like flashlight head over to black magic craft dot CA there I have my
essential equipment page where I link all of the stuff that I use regularly so
you can make sure you're getting the right thing and have it shipped
conveniently to your door also if you enjoy these videos that I
make each and every week if you truly get some tangible value out of them if
they improve your life consider supporting the channel on patreon that
support is really crucial to allowing me to make them every week and I'd
to have you as the newest member of the black magic crafts fellowship that's it
for this week guys I will see you again next week
Cheers
